data.title: Finally!
data.text:
I have been meaning to eat at The Dev for months and finally got a chance to!  I went with a friend and her toddler, which we thought at first might be an issue, but it wasn't at all!  The waitress was great, really accommodating. She even offered to slice up apples with peanut butter for the baby, which was perfect.

I ordered the Utican and it was delicious. The chef came out to talk to us about substituting sides and what they had fresh in the kitchen. I was bummed because they were out of their normal side and offered us chips instead, which was fine but not exactly what I'd wanted.

The inside is really interesting. It has an old feel to it, but with a lot of modern updates. We will definitely go again!

data.title: Potential, but pass
data.text: I can't imagine regulars going here on your lunch break. Wraps took almost an hour by the time our order was taken and the food was brought to our table. Only 3 other tables there and maybe 3 at the bar... It was bafflingly slow. The wraps were just "ok". Too much mayo, too little everything else... Including flavor. Very anti climatic. I really wanted to like this place with the neat indie vibe but think it's best viewed as a watering hole (definitely not a microbrewery as it calls itself?). I wish them luck, they seem nice, but they need more help in the kitchen.

data.title: Trendy and tasty
data.text: No frier in this place, so you get fresh salads, inventive sides with your sandwiches - just neat, trendy dishes.  Top it off with Drunken Cupcake for dessert, you can't go wrong.

data.title: Nice little spot
data.text: Have been here few times for lunch, tried their fish tacos recently, awesome, never disappointed in my selections and food comes out fast, overall a good experience each time!

data.title: Friendly little indie rock bar
data.text: I like to go into a new city and be treated as though I were a local, even when I ask dumb questions, as I did in this charming little club right off Main Street.  The bartender gave me a quick survey of the Utica spots to check out.  Later that night at the Dev I saw 3 bands for 5 bucks and the microbrews flowed freely.  I'd rather be at the Dev than the various beer halls over in the other part of town.

data.title: Great place for a drink and noontime meal
data.text:
OK, I'll admit it. I only stopped into The Dev yesterday because I was lost in Utica and I really had to find a bathroom quickly. But I am very glad that I did stop in, as it was lunchtime and I doubt that I could have found a better place had I tried. As the friendly bartender told me, The Dev, which had been known and operated under a slightly different name, had a rather checkered past before closing due to physical and clientele issue. The new staff has come in and completely cleaned out the place, starting from scratch...and they've done a great job of it!

I decided to eat lunch there, and ordered a chicken salad Panini sandwich. The plate arrived in just a few minutes, and presented a creative variation on the standard dish. The chicken salad was chopped quite finely, and then combined into a curry-flavored pate, which was then layered onto the Panini with a slightly sweet chutney and some spring lettuce sprigs. It was very tasty, and accompanied by a side order of seasoned garbanzo bean salad. Very nice!

The inside of the bar/restaurant was decorated with the works of some local artists, which are rotated on a monthly basis. Above the bar were displayed an array of early-1900s radios, with their wooden cases an old-fashioned dials.

This was a really nice break in my day, made all the more pleasant by the conversation of the female bartender and male co-worker...very nice people! I would love to come back for another visit my next trip through Utica.

data.title: Has potential...but not quite there, yet
data.text:
I was super excited to try the food at "The Dev" before a show last night.  The Devereaux has had its ups and downs over the years and the "new" version looked like they'd really made some things happen.  The menu looked inviting, the place was cleaned up, the beer selection is excellent, so we headed over ready to enjoy.  The beer selection and atmosphere held up their end of the bargain.  But the dinner part, not so much.  It wasn't really the food.  The food was decent.  I ordered the arugula salad (it came without a leaf of arugula) but was tasty just the same, although a bit heavy-handed on the sundried tomatoes.  I also ordered the hummus wrap, which was good, although the hummus was a little bland.  The major problem was the service.  We arrived around 7:45pm and there was another couple already dining.  I didn't see anyone else ordering food or eating.  So that was it, a table of two and the three of us.  We ordered -- an appetizer, three salads and three sandwiches (two hummus wraps and an egg, ham and swiss grilled sandwich).  About 20 minutes later (yes, I said 20 minutes) two of the sandwiches arrive.  No silverware, just two of our sandwiches (the cold hummus ones).  No appetizer, no salads first, just sandwiches. Then, we sit for at least another 4 minutes - looking at the "hot" sandwich sitting on the ledge of the kitchen service window.  We could see it!  What we couldn't see was our waitress.   Gone -- literally -- not visible anywhere.  We watched a number of employees look at the sandwich and walk away.  At one point, a friend of mine stood up to start walking over and grab it herself.  Then the waitress appeared.  She brought the "lukewarm" sandwich and everything else that we'd ordered -- all at once.  The food was ok. The appetizer, blue cheese crostini -- was really quite yummy, but hard to enjoy with a table full of our dinner.

So, I imagine that if they get their "thang" together -- it could be a decent place.  But I'm not all that impressed right this minute.

data.title: Best lunch in Downtown Utica
data.text: I had lunch at this recently remodeled downtown landmark.  The new owners have done a fantastic job of bringing this iconic spot back to life.  The menu is diverse with a flair for unique flavors.  The soup of the day was carrot ginger, which was out of this world as was the grilled cheese sandwich with sun-dried tomato pesto.  Prices are very reasonable. The Dev is a definite must on the Utica lunch list.
